content.raw: It would be interesting to compare the performance of std::map vs std::unordered_map. Remember me to write a test for this.
content.html: It would be interesting to compare the performance of std::map vs std::unordered_map. Remember me to write a test for this.

content.raw: On paper, std::unordered_map should be faster for our use case because we don't need sorted keys and we don't iterate over all the elements. Our use case is ideal for std::unordered_map. Unordered_map uses a hash instead of a tree and I read that the hash function doesn't work really well with strings as keys. So, we should benchmark it before changing it. It's an interesting topic!
content.html: On paper, std::unordered_map should be faster for our use case because we don't need sorted keys and we don't iterate over all the elements. Our use case is ideal for std::unordered_map. Unordered_map uses a hash instead of a tree and I read that the hash function doesn't work really well with strings as keys. So, we should benchmark it before changing it. It's an interesting topic!

content.html: Updated: I've created a separate class for managing UUIDs. It will be easy to make UUIDs portable.

In debian/ubuntu, they are shipping this header together with zeromq package. For homebrew, I've [imported it](https://github.com/j-rivero/homebrew-simulation/blob/master/cppzmq.rb) from https://github.com/bertjwregeer/homebrew-compat/

**update:** it is a good idea to include it in the SearchForStuff. I've created the branch ```transport_0.3.0_jrivero``` and commited af1e953 to make this possible. Tested on Linux.

content.raw:
That was excellent intuition, recompiling protobuf with `--c++11` fixed the build, though it gave an ominous warning:
~~~
Warning: ignition-transport dependency boost was built with a different C++ standard
library (libstdc++ from clang). This could cause problems at runtime.
~~~
boost is a transitive dependency from robot_msgs. I think it would be best to keep robot_msgs from depending on boost ([issue here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/robot_msgs/issue/3/remove-boost-dependency))
content.html:
That was excellent intuition, recompiling protobuf with --c++11 fixed the build, though it gave an ominous warning:

Warning: ignition-transport dependency boost was built with a different C++ standard
library (libstdc++ from clang). This could cause problems at runtime.

boost is a transitive dependency from robot_msgs. I think it would be best to keep robot_msgs from depending on boost (issue here)

content.raw: I just created a [pull request for removing the boost dependency](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/robot_msgs/pull-request/5/) in robot_msgs. Let me know if that solves the problem.
content.html: I just created a pull request for removing the boost dependency in robot_msgs. Let me know if that solves the problem.

content.html: I'll try to move robot_msgs into ignition and remove the dependency on boost.

content.raw:
Update on mac osx status:

I can build successfully on osx with the following commands:
~~~
brew tap osrf/simulation
# robot_msgs --HEAD uses c++11 branch
brew install robot_msgs --HEAD
# need to run a second time due to weird behavior related to our custom protobuf formula
brew install robot_msgs --HEAD
brew install ignition-transport --HEAD
~~~

It has a few compiler warnings. Also the tests are failing. @caguero is looking into the failing tests.

There are also a few homebrew warnings on osx 10.8 that are resolved on 10.9. This is related to libstdc++ vs. libc++ and libc++ is required for c++11.
content.html:
Update on mac osx status:

I can build successfully on osx with the following commands:

brew tap osrf/simulation
# robot_msgs --HEAD uses c++11 branch
brew install robot_msgs --HEAD
# need to run a second time due to weird behavior related to our custom protobuf formula
brew install robot_msgs --HEAD
brew install ignition-transport --HEAD

It has a few compiler warnings. Also the tests are failing. @caguero is looking into the failing tests.

There are also a few homebrew warnings on osx 10.8 that are resolved on 10.9. This is related to libstdc++ vs. libc++ and libc++ is required for c++11.
